title: Unable to launch Visual Studio developer command prompt from tasks.json
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
Parsing of tasks,json seems to ignore escaped characters in strings, this means that you cannot pass a path to a file / executable that contains spaces.
 
- VS Code Version: 1.103.1
- OS Version: Windows 11 (Windows_NT x64 10.0.22631)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install Visual Studio
2. Configure tasks.json to use a visual studio developer command prompt:
```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "windows": {
        "options": {
            "shell": {
                "executable": "cmd.exe",
                "args": [
                    "/d",
                    "/c",
                    "\"C:/Program Files/Microsoft Visual Studio/2022/Professional/VC/Auxiliary/Build/vcvars64.bat\"",
                    "&"
                ]
            }
        }
    },
    "tasks": [
        {
            "label": "CMake test",
            "type": "shell",
            "command": "cmake",
            "args": [
                "--version",
            ],
            "problemMatcher": [],
            "group": {
                "kind": "build",
                "isDefault": false
            }
        }
    ]
}
```
3. Running the task "CMake test" causes the following error:
```
 *  Executing task: cmake --version 

'C:/Program' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.

 *  The terminal process "cmd.exe /d /c "C:/Program Files/Microsoft Visual Studio/2022/Professional/VC/Auxiliary/Build/vcvars64.bat" & "cmake --version"" terminated with exit code: 1. 
```

With version 1.102 this works and produces a valid terminal. 

The structure of tasks.json follows the structure given in VSCode documentation: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/cpp/config-msvc#_run-vs-code-outside-the-developer-command-prompt

title: improve processing auto experiment settings scheduler
VS Code OAuth2 Flow Violates RFC 9728: 3.3. Protected Resource Metadata Validation

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Type: Bug 1. Register a local MCP server, example `mcp.json`: ``` { "servers": { "local": { "url": "http://localhost:3001", "type": "http" } }, "inputs": [] } ``` 2. Ensure this server is running and exposes a Resource of `http://localhost:3001`. 3. Start the server in VS Code 4. Observe log and error message: ``` 2025-08-19 08:45:12.829 [info] Stopping server local 2025-08-19 08:45:12.846 [info] Starting server local 2025-08-19 08:45:12.847 [info] Connection state: Starting 2025-08-19 08:45:12.852 [info] Starting server from LocalProcess extension host 2025-08-19 08:45:12.875 [info] Connection state: Running 2025-08-19 08:45:12.918 [info] Connection state: Error Error sending message to http://localhost:3001/: Error: Protected Resource Metadata resource "http://localhost:3001" does not match MCP server resolved resource "http://localhost:3001/". The MCP server must follow OAuth spec https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9728#PRConfigurationValidation 2025-08-19 08:45:12.918 [error] Server exited before responding to `initialize` request. ``` 5. Note: `Error sending message to http://localhost:3001/: Error: Protected Resource Metadata resource "http://localhost:3001" does not match MCP server resolved resource "http://localhost:3001/". The MCP server must follow OAuth spec https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9728#PRConfigurationValidation` 6. Note that it appears that VS Code sent a request to a URI with a terminating slash ('/') despite that not being configured. 7. Updating the MCP server to expose its resource as "http://localhost:3001/" fixes the issue, however this does not follow the MCP Authorization spec: https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/2025-06-18/basic/authorization. This spec states: ` Note: While both https://mcp.example.com/ (with trailing slash) and https://mcp.example.com (without trailing slash) are technically valid absolute URIs according to [RFC 3986](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986), implementations SHOULD consistently use the form without the trailing slash for better interoperability unless the trailing slash is semantically significant for the specific resource. ` Sniffing around the VS Code codebase I observe that the check for equality [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/workbench/api/common/extHostMcp.ts#L338) constructs the strings as `new URL(url).toString()` whereas in other parts of the application this variant is invoked `this._launch.uri.toString(true),`. Perhaps this inconsistency is the cause - I didn't spend long looking around for the root cause. VS Code version: Code 1.102.2 (c306e94f98122556ca081f527b466015e1bc37b0, 2025-07-22T12:15:48.520Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 Modes:

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->

<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: any
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run VS Code when an update is available, long enough for the update to be downloaded in the background
2. Shut down the computer while VS Code is running: Windows will be waiting for programs to finish, among which the VS Code installer
3. Wait for the computer to shut down completely
4. Start the computer back up: your shortcuts to VS Code will be left dangling
5. Go the the installation directory: you will find that Code.exe and most other files are missing
6. The new version will be installed in a subdirectory named "_"

What I expected to happen: VS Code is installed properly, with no dangling shortcuts

title: Fix smoke test directory conflicts by adding unique workspace path suffixes
body:
## Problem

Smoke tests for different configurations (Electron, Web, Remote) were using the same hardcoded workspace directory `vscode-smoketest-express`, causing conflicts when tests run concurrently. This led to test failures and unreliable CI/CD execution.

## Root Cause

Both `test/smoke/src/main.ts` and `test/mcp/src/playwright.ts` used hardcoded workspace paths:

```typescript
const workspacePath = path.join(testDataPath, 'vscode-smoketest-express');
```

When multiple test configurations ran simultaneously, they would attempt to use the same directory, causing file system conflicts and test failures.

## Solution

Added a `getTestTypeSuffix()` helper function that returns unique suffixes based on test configuration:

- **Web tests**: `browser` suffix → `vscode-smoketest-express-browser`
- **Remote tests**: `remote` suffix → `vscode-smoketest-express-remote`  
- **Electron tests**: `electron` suffix → `vscode-smoketest-express-electron`

This follows the existing pattern already used for logs and crashes directories in both files.

## Changes

- Added `getTestTypeSuffix()` function to both test files
- Updated `workspacePath` to use dynamic suffixes: `vscode-smoketest-express-${getTestTypeSuffix()}`
- Maintains full backward compatibility
- Ensures unique workspace directories for concurrent test execution

## Testing

Verified that:
- Each test type gets its own unique workspace directory
- No more conflicts when running tests concurrently
- Existing functionality remains unchanged
- TypeScript syntax is correct
- Follows established code patterns

This fix ensures reliable concurrent execution of smoke tests across different VS Code configurations.

title: Implement workspace-aware default window sizing with unified API (1440x900 for workspaces, 1200x800 for empty windows)
body:
This PR introduces differentiated default window sizes based on whether VS Code is opening a workspace or an empty window, providing a better user experience for workspace-based development.

## Changes

### New Window Sizing Logic
- **Workspace windows**: Now default to 1440x900 pixels (larger size for better workspace visibility)
- **Empty windows**: Continue using 1200x800 pixels (preserves existing behavior)

### Implementation Details

**Updated constants:**
- Renamed `DEFAULT_WINDOW_SIZE` to `DEFAULT_EMPTY_WINDOW_SIZE` (1200x800) for clarity
- Added `DEFAULT_WORKSPACE_WINDOW_SIZE` constant (1440x900) in `src/vs/platform/window/common/window.ts`

**Unified window state API:**
- Enhanced `defaultWindowState()` in `src/vs/platform/window/electron-main/window.ts` to accept optional `isWorkspace` parameter
- Automatically selects appropriate window size based on workspace context
- Maintains backward compatibility with existing calls

**Enhanced window state detection:**
- Modified `doGetNewWindowState()` in `src/vs/platform/windows/electron-main/windowsStateHandler.ts`
- Uses `isWorkspaceIdentifier()` and `isSingleFolderWorkspaceIdentifier()` to detect workspace context
- Calls `defaultWindowState(WindowMode.Normal, hasWorkspace)` with appropriate workspace flag

**Improved layout fallback:**
- Updated `src/vs/workbench/browser/layout.ts` to use larger workspace dimensions as fallback
- Provides better default sizing for layout calculations

## Backward Compatibility

This change is fully backward compatible:
- Empty windows maintain the existing 1200x800 default size
- All existing configuration options (`window.newWindowDimensions`) continue to work as before
- Stored window states and user preferences are unaffected
- Existing `defaultWindowState()` calls without the new parameter work unchanged

## Workspace Detection

The implementation correctly identifies workspaces in two scenarios:
1. **Multi-root workspaces**: `.code-workspace` files (`isWorkspaceIdentifier`)
2. **Single folder workspaces**: Individual folders (`isSingleFolderWorkspaceIdentifier`)

Both workspace types receive the larger 1440x900 default window size, while truly empty VS Code windows (no folder or workspace) maintain the smaller 1200x800 size.

This enhancement improves the out-of-box experience for developers working with workspaces by providing more screen real estate for code, file trees, and panels without affecting users who prefer to start with empty windows.

title: July 2025 Recovery 2

labels.name: endgame-plan
labels.description: VS Code - Next release plan for endgame

body:
<!--
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
!!                                WARNING                                     !!
!!                                                                            !!
!! DO NOT COPY/PASTE THIS TEMPLATE TO CREATE AN ENDGAME PLAN MANUALLY.        !!
!! Instead, use https://tools.code.visualstudio.com/duties/endgame to create  !!
!! the endgame plan automatically.                                            !!
!! For more information check                                                 !!
!! https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Running-the-Endgame               !!
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
-->

- [x] Create a milestone `July 2025 Recovery 2` **@osortega**
- [x] Bump the version number & run `npm i` to bump `package-lock.json` as well. Ensure there are no other `package-lock.json` changes. **@osortega**
- [x] [🔖candidate issues](https://github.com/issues?q=org%3Amicrosoft%20is%3Aissue%20milestone%3A%22July%202025%20Recovery%202%22%20label%3Acandidate)
- [x] Assign candidate issues to the recovery milestone **team**
- [x] Review the `candidate` issues, and if they pass the review assign them to the recovery milestone **team**
- [x] All `candidate` fixes are peer reviewed and pushed to `main` and then cherry-picked into the release branch **team**
- [x] Initiate `insiders` build from `main`
- [x] Issues are tested in the `insiders` **team**
- [x] Build and manually release Insider from main branch for vscode.dev (if there were vscode.dev candidates)
  - [x] Issues are tested in the `insiders` **team**
- [x] Build `stable` for all platforms from release branch **@osortega**
- [x] Issues are verified on `stable` build and the `verified` label is added **@osortega**
- [x] Check `https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/compare/release/<x.y>` to ensure no other commits have been made in the release branch **@osortega**
- [x] The `insiders` build with all candidate fixes needs to be in the wild for 24 hours before recovery release, unless explicitly approved by @kieferrm
- [x] Update the release notes and include a link to a query for the fixed issues **@ntrogh**
- [x] [Sanity Testing](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Sanity-Check)
  - [x] Windows 64 bit **@hediet**
    - [x] System Installer
    - [x] User Installer
    - [x] Archive
    - [x] Server
    - [x] CLI

    - [x] User Installer
    - [x] Archive
    - [x] Server
    - [x] CLI

    - [x] Server
    - [x] CLI

    - [x] Archive

    - [x] Archive

- [x] Publish website **@rzhao271**

- [x] Create an official release **@osortega**
  - [x] Create a tag (make sure you pull the release branch first): `git tag <x.y.z> release/<x.y>`
  - [x] Push the tag: `git push origin <x.y.z>`
  - [x] Create a GitHub release: [Open the GitHub tags](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/tags), and click far right `... > Create Release`. Use the correct title and description from our release notes. [Example](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.81.1)
- [x] Close the milestone on [GitHub](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/milestones) **@osortega**

title: feat: Add Swipe to Navigate for macOS touchpads.
body:
Edit: [Alternative implementation](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/262262) registers the swipe recognizers and expose them as an extension API instead: 

Following options have been added:

- 	`"disabled"` – Disable swipe navigation.
- 	`"editor"` – Switch editor tabs across all groups (previous/next).
- 	`"editorInGroup"` – Switch editor tabs within the current group only (previous/next).
- 	`"history"` – Move through most recently used editors (MRU) across all groups (previous/next).
- 	`"historyInGroup"` – Move through most recently used editors (MRU) within the current group (previous/next).
- 	`"group"` – Change focus to neighboring editor groups (left/right/up/down).
- 	`"navigation"` – Move through navigational history (for example: Go To References).
- 	`"edit"` – Navigate cursor edit locations.
- 	`"navigationEdit"` – Navigate through a combined history of navigation and edit locations.

Alternatively, the setting can be defined as an object:

```json 
"workbench.editor.swipeToNavigate": {
  "horizontal": "navigationEdit",
  "vertical": "disabled"
}
```

Can also support custom actions: 
```json
"workbench.editor.swipeToNavigate": {
  "horizontal": "disabled",
  "vertical": { "previous": "commandId1", "next": "commandId2" }
}
```

Requires these OS settings: 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/09e72ba6-7ae2-467f-b379-dde1b9455ae2)

Older OS settings: 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/895e540f-dc46-4d18-9f7a-7aa0516cebbc)


Also I think there is a misunderstanding in previous threads, swipes don't work unless you activate them on OS level (as per screenshot). There is a distinction between swiping and panning, the latter is fullscreen.  
It is very possible that you had [disabled](https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/19131#issuecomment-613751165) them on your OS level and assumed they didn't work.

Previous discussions with @bpasero indicated there was no interest in adding more Electron APIs. However, Electron applications such as Discord have supported swipe gestures for years without issues, and Touch Bar integration is already supported and that uses Electron APIs. Swipe gestures have been stable in Electron for a long time and have not caused problems, outside of that misunderstanding

~~Another option would be to expose events for extensions, though I am not sure how to get started with that. I assume it would require approval before introducing a new extension API.~~

I previously attempted this through an [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Seivan.swipe-to-navigate), but it relied on heavy hacks and monkey-patching the bootloader. These broke with every VS Code update and were difficult to maintain, since I had to inspect the generated JavaScript to figure out where to apply the patches. This approach is unsustainable.

I rely on swipe gestures for navigation as an accessibility feature. Swiping to move between views is a native macOS behavior supported in Xcode, Safari, Finder, Terminal, Notes, and more. The lack of support in VS Code feels inconsistent with the platform.

At the very least, the swipe gesture recognizers should be exposed via an extension like the alternative PR https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/262262 and let extensions (I've done one) define actions for them. 

Discussions:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/4803 (again)
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/40526
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/25447
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/25325
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/25449

title: Fix Chat Session Migration Actions to Open Existing Sessions Instead of Creating New Ones
body:
The chat session migration actions (Move to New Editor, Move to New Window, Move to Side Bar) were creating new empty chat sessions instead of opening the selected existing session with its complete conversation history.

## Problem

When users right-clicked on an extension-contributed chat session and selected migration actions like "Move to New Editor to the Side" or "Move to New Window", the actions would create new empty chat sessions instead of migrating the selected session. This happened because the implementation was using `ChatEditorInput.getNewEditorUri()` (which creates new empty sessions) and trying to pass the existing sessionId through options.

## Solution

Fixed the actions to use the proper URI scheme for extension-contributed sessions:

1. **Proper URI Creation**: Now uses `ChatSessionUri.forSession(chatSessionType, sessionId)` which creates URIs with the `vscodeChatSession` scheme
2. **Session Type Detection**: Extracts the `chatSessionType` from the marshalled context's provider information 
3. **Correct Session Loading**: When `ChatEditorInput.resolve()` processes a `vscodeChatSession` scheme URI, it calls `loadSessionForResource()` which properly loads extension-contributed sessions with their complete history
4. **Proper Sidebar Handling**: Uses `viewsService.openView<ChatViewPane>()` and `loadSession()` to correctly move sessions to the sidebar

## Actions Implemented

- **Move to New Editor to the Side** (`workbench.action.chat.moveSessionToNewEditor`): Migrates the session to a new editor tab in the side group
- **Move to New Window** (`workbench.action.chat.moveSessionToNewWindow`): Migrates the session to a new auxiliary window with compact layout
- **Move to Side Bar** (`workbench.action.chat.moveSessionToSideBar`): Migrates the session back to the sidebar panel, properly closing any existing editors

All actions now preserve complete session history and state when migrating between locations. The actions appear in the context menu for extension-contributed sessions only, grouped separately from extension actions under the "migration" group.

title: Integrate chat session monitoring into existing Copilot status bar dashboard with performance optimizations
body:
This PR integrates in-progress chat session monitoring into the existing Copilot status bar entry's hover dashboard, providing users with a unified view of all Copilot-related information while optimizing performance through intelligent caching.

## Problem

Users currently have no visual indication of chat sessions that are actively processing in the background. Additionally, multiple UI components were making separate calls to chat session providers, leading to redundant operations and performance issues.

## Solution

**Integrated Dashboard Approach**: Instead of adding a separate status bar entry, running chat sessions are now displayed within the existing 🤖 Copilot status bar entry's hover tooltip. This provides a cleaner, more unified user experience.

**Running Sessions Section**: The dashboard now includes a dedicated "Running Sessions" section that shows:
- Individual sessions with spinning progress icons
- Session names and "In progress" status  
- Summary count (e.g., "Working on 3 sessions")
- Quick access to the Chat Sessions view via "View Sessions" button

**Performance Optimization**: Added intelligent 5-second caching to `ChatSessionsService.provideChatSessionItems` that:
- Eliminates redundant provider calls when multiple consumers need session data
- Automatically invalidates cache when providers fire `onDidChangeChatSessionItems` events
- Provides significant performance benefits for extension-contributed providers that may perform expensive operations

## Implementation Details

- **Unified UI**: Extended `ChatStatusDashboard` in `chatStatus.ts` to include running sessions alongside existing quota and settings information
- **Clean Architecture**: Removed the separate `ChatSessionsStatusBarEntry` to avoid UI clutter while preserving all functionality
- **Error Handling**: Graceful degradation if individual providers fail, ensuring the dashboard remains functional
- **Responsive Design**: Sessions appear automatically when active and disappear when complete

## User Experience

Users now get a comprehensive view of all Copilot-related information in a single, well-organized hover tooltip. This makes it easier to monitor chat session progress, manage quotas, and adjust settings all from one central location.

<screenshot>
![Chat Status Dashboard Integration](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0544b501-b92a-401f-ae73-d78d6990511e)
</screenshot>

Files modified:
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatStatus.ts` - Extended dashboard with running sessions section
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chat.contribution.ts` - Removed separate status bar entry registration  
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatSessions.contribution.ts` - Added caching to ChatSessionsService
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/media/chatStatus.css` - Added styles for session items

Files removed:
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatSessionsStatusBarEntry.ts` - No longer needed
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/test/browser/chatSessionsStatusBarEntry.test.ts` - No longer needed

title: [WIP] Complete Chat Sessions Tree View Implementation
body:
Coding agent has begun work on **Complete Chat Sessions Tree View Implementation** and will replace this description as work progresses.

<details><summary>See problem context</summary>

This PR completes the chat sessions tree view implementation by:

## 🎯 Implementation Details

### Core Features Implemented:
- ✅ **Tree View Infrastructure**: Leverages existing VS Code tree view APIs (`IAsyncDataSource`, `ITreeRenderer`, etc.)
- ✅ **Session Provider Architecture**: Uses existing `IChatSessionsService` and provider pattern
- ✅ **Action System**: Integrates with VS Code's menu system (`MenuId.ChatSessionsMenu`)
- ✅ **Context Menu Support**: Full context menu with marshalled contexts for commands
- ✅ **Inline Actions**: Session items show relevant actions inline
- ✅ **Rename Functionality**: Built-in session renaming with proper validation
- ✅ **Multi-Provider Support**: Handles local sessions and extension-provided sessions
- ✅ **Configuration-Driven**: View location configurable via settings
- ✅ **Progress Indicators**: Shows loading states during data fetch
- ✅ **Empty State Handling**: Proper empty state messages for different scenarios

### Architecture Highlights:
- **Uses existing APIs**: No reinventing the wheel - leverages `WorkbenchAsyncDataTree`, `ViewPaneContainer`, etc.
- **Service Integration**: Properly integrated with `IChatSessionsService`, `IChatWidgetService`, `IEditorService`
- **Event-Driven**: Responsive to session changes with proper event handling
- **Disposed Resources**: Proper cleanup and disposal patterns throughout
- **Type Safety**: Full TypeScript support with proper interfaces and type guards
- **Accessibility**: Follows VS Code accessibility patterns with proper ARIA labels

### Key Components:

#### 1. **ChatSessionsViewPaneContainer**
- Main container managing multiple session provider views
- Dynamic view registration based on available providers
- Handles provider lifecycle and view updates

#### 2. **SessionsViewPane** 
- Individual tree view for each session provider
- Async data loading with progress indication
- Context menu and inline actions support
- Empty state handling

#### 3. **LocalChatSessionsProvider**
- Tracks open chat editors and panel widgets as sessions
- Real-time updates when editors/widgets are added/removed/renamed
- Maintains consistent ordering of session items

#### 4. **SessionsRenderer**
- Custom tree renderer with action bar support
- Handles different icon types (ThemeIcon, URI, etc.)
- Inline rename functionality with input validation
- Proper resource label formatting

#### 5. **Action Integration**
- `RenameChatSessionAction` - Rename local sessions with F2 keybinding
- Menu contributions for `MenuId.ChatSessionsMenu`
- Context-aware action visibility based on session type
- Marshalled contexts for proper command execution

### Configuration:
```jsonc
{
  "chat.agentSessionsViewLocation": "view" // or "hidden" to disable
}
```

### Extension Point Usage:
The implementation properly uses the existing `chatSessions` extension point:
```jsonc
{
  "contributes": {
    "chatSessions": [
      {
        "type": "my-provider",
        "name": "My Sessions",
        "displayName": "My Custom Sessions",
        "description": "Custom session provider"
      }
    ]
  }
}
```

### Technical Implementation:
- **No Breaking Changes**: All existing APIs remain unchanged
- **Backwards Compatible**: Works with existing chat session providers
- **Performance Optimized**: Efficient tree updates and minimal re-renders
- **Memory Efficient**: Proper disposal and cleanup of resources
- **Error Handling**: Robust error handling with fallbacks
- **Testing Ready**: Clean separation of concerns for unit testing

This implementation follows VS Code's established patterns and integrates seamlessly with the existing chat architecture while providing a robust, extensible tree view for managing chat sessions.

</details>

title: Experiment with disabling insert_edit_into_file for GPT-5

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as probable candidate for fixing in the next release

body: GPT-5 is very good at using apply_patch, and we've seen some reported edit issues/slowness is actually because GPT-5 does not prefer apply_patch _as_ strongly as 4.1/4o when instructed to do so (or maybe used as a fallback with https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/262217). We should experiment with phasing out insert_edit for GPT-5.

title: apply_patch fails with the "Add File" operation

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as probable candidate for fixing in the next release

body:
Codex's apply_patch operation supports "Add File". We kind of do, but it was never validated fully and we don't include "Add File" in our instructions. Regardless, GPT-5 frequently emits the instruction and this causes an error in our agent. This is pretty easy to repro with the query:

```
Use the apply_patch tool with the undocumented "Add File" operation to create hello.md with the contents "foo"
```

title: Add hierarchical chat history tree view to LocalChatSessionsProvider
body:
This PR adds a hierarchical tree view for chat history in the LocalChatSessionsProvider, following VS Code's standard tree view patterns used in file explorer and search results.

## Overview

Instead of a flat list approach, the implementation now uses a proper parent-child tree structure where "Previous Chats" appears as a collapsible parent node containing individual historical chat sessions as children.

## Tree Structure

```
📁 Chat Sessions
├── 💬 Current Chat Session 1  
├── 💬 Current Chat Session 2
└── 📂 Previous Chats (N)         ← Collapsible parent node
    ├── 🕒 Historical Chat 1      ← Child items
    └── 🕒 Historical Chat 2
```

## Implementation Details

### Tree Hierarchy Types
- **IChatHistoryParentItem**: Parent node that contains historical session data
- **IChatHistoryItem**: Individual historical sessions as tree children
- **Proper type hierarchy**: All items extend IChatSessionItem for compatibility

### Data Source Architecture
- **SessionsDataSource.hasChildren()**: Returns true for provider and history parent nodes
- **SessionsDataSource.getChildren()**: 
  - Provider → Active sessions + History parent (if history exists)
  - History parent → Individual historical sessions
  - Other items → Empty array

### Built-in Tree Behavior
- **Automatic expand/collapse**: Leverages tree view's native expansion mechanisms
- **No manual state management**: Removed custom `isHistoryExpanded` logic
- **Standard interaction**: Follows VS Code tree view patterns users expect

### User Experience
1. **Active sessions** display at root level as before
2. **"Previous Chats (N)"** appears as expandable parent when history exists
3. **Clicking parent** expands/collapses using tree view built-in behavior
4. **Clicking history items** opens them in new chat editors
5. **Visual hierarchy** uses standard tree indentation and icons

## Technical Benefits

- **Follows VS Code patterns**: Same architecture as file explorer, search tree, etc.
- **Leverages existing infrastructure**: Uses tree view's built-in parent-child handling
- **Cleaner codebase**: Removes custom expansion state management
- **Better performance**: Tree view handles virtualization and expansion efficiently
- **Maintainable**: Standard patterns are easier to understand and extend

This approach provides the same functionality as before but with proper hierarchical structure that integrates seamlessly with VS Code's tree view architecture.

* Create a read notebook file tool
* Include line numbers in notebook summary output (line numbers for each cells), so model can use read file tool with the line args.

title: VSCode uses wrong authorization URL when connecting to an MCP server with Oauth

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No - VS Code Version: 1.103.0 - OS Version: Mac OS 15.3.1 Steps to Reproduce: 1. I have an MCP server running at https://freddyaboulton-fastmcp-oauth.hf.space/mcp. It's code is [here](https://huggingface.co/spaces/freddyaboulton/fastmcp-oauth/blob/main/app.py) 2. This is what `/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource` returns ```json { "resource": "https://freddyaboulton-fastmcp-oauth.hf.space/mcp", "authorization_servers": [ "https://huggingface.co/.well-known/oauth-authorization-server" ], "scopes_supported": [ "inference-api" ], "bearer_methods_supported": [ "header" ] } ``` and this is what `/.well-known/oauth-authorization-server` returns ```json { "issuer": "https://huggingface.co", "registration_endpoint": "https://huggingface.co/oauth/register", "token_endpoint": "https://huggingface.co/oauth/token", "authorization_endpoint": "https://huggingface.co/oauth/authorize", "userinfo_endpoint": "https://huggingface.co/oauth/userinfo", "token_endpoint_auth_signing_alg_values_supported": [ "HS256" ], "jwks_uri": "https://huggingface.co/oauth/jwks", "response_types_supported": [ "code" ], "grant_types_supported": [ "authorization_code", "refresh_token" ], "response_modes_supported": [ "query" ], "id_token_signing_alg_values_supported": [ "RS256" ], "subject_types_supported": [ "public" ], "code_challenge_methods_supported": [ "S256" ], "token_endpoint_auth_methods_supported": [ "client_secret_basic", "client_secret_jwt", "client_secret_post" ] } ``` When I connect via vs code, the client uses `https://freddyaboulton-fastmcp-oauth.hf.space/authorize?...` instead of the `authorization_endpoint` returned by `/.well-known/oauth-authorization-server` so the OAuth flow fails

title: Deprecate ChatParticipant#onDidReceiveFeedback

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

body:
We'd like to remove the 👍 / 👎  buttons from chat respones to clean up the toolbar, and since we believe that we have better quality signals.

The complication is that `ChatParticipant#onDidReceiveFeedback` is finalized API. But I think it's worth deprecating this, which would mean turning that event in a no-op.
